column1: Will Prayut Chan-o-cha cease to be the prime minister of Thailand before 23 April 2021?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']
Not enough political pressure for him to leave

Jatuporn calls for unity in seeking Prayut's removal - The Phuket News https://www.thephuketnews.com/jatuporn-calls-for-unity-in-seeking-prayut-removal-79569.php Mon, 05 Apr 2021 07:00:00 GMT Small protest, no change in forecast. All quiet on the reddit.com/r/Thailand/ front, though some of the posts can be pretty funny (i.e. https://www.reddit.com/r/Thailand/comments/mpbq4j/prayuth_unlocked_his_golden_skin_after_being_an/)

Currently, the Thai government has chosen to intensify police response to the protests instead of compromising with the protests. This is a clear indication by the Prime Minister and his government that they will not concede and give up power. The Prime Minister has reiterated that he views the protests as illegal and thus would not warrant him stepping down from power. Prayut is also a staunch pro-monarchy leader, and because the protesters are criticizing the monarchy, him resining due to those protesters would hurt his image.
No change.
consensus for many months
No change
Time update

Considering the timeline of this issue - that the coup happened in 2014, Prayut Chan-o-cha was sworn in in June 2020, and student protests have been happening since August 2020 - it has been a long timeline, and I don‚Äôt predict that there is a high likelihood of this changing in the next month and a half. He was even acquitted by court in December 2020 after being brought up on ethical charges (Tanakasempipat, P., & Thepgumpanat, P., 2020).
Probability is vanishingly small given the timeframe

"In Thailand, although the Siamese Revolution of 1932 marked the start of a Thai democratic tradition, instability and conflicts over political power between the bureaucrats and military were incessant. Coups became a frequent means to seize power, and democratic election results were often diminished. There were 13 successful coups, the most recent of which took place in 2014, led by General Prayut Chan-o-cha, who is in charge of the current government. Unlike other constitutional monarchies like the U.K. or Japan, the Thai monarchy has a robust role in domestic politics. Hence, the military junta in Thailand has relied on the royal sovereign‚Äôs approval as one of the sources of its legitimacy, and democracy was sidelined as a core value. Because public demands do not necessarily challenge the legitimacy of the government, calls for democracy were more easily overlooked." https://thediplomat.com/2021/03/can-southeast-asia-follow-south-koreas-democratization-model/ It may happen, but even though protests intensified in the past few days, it's unlikely to happen by 23 April 2021.

Myanmar junta leader asks Thai counterpart Prayut for help on democracy - The Straits Times https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/myanmar-junta-leader-asks-thai-counterpart-for-help-on-democracy Wed, 10 Feb 2021 08:26:27 GMT

Thailand revives prison terms for royal insults to stop protests - The Japan Times https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/02/03/asia-pacific/thailand-king-insult-penalties/ Wed, 03 Feb 2021 04:43:00 GMT

Monarchy has cracked down on protests and despite popular discontent Prayut Chan-o-cha has maintained his hold on power. If he was not ousted by the protests last year it is unlikely that he will cease to be prime minister in the near future. The short timespan of this question also decreases the likelihood of the answer being 'Yes.'

https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/thailand-protests-youth/ The current crop of demonstrators wants three things: this guy to resign, a new constitution, and curbs on royal powers. Throwing Prayut off the sleigh to the wolves is the only one that might happen this time, and it would be fairly easy and painless for his loyal friends and colleagues to do. Coming up a bit, for a while.

Worth keeping an eye on. I‚Äôm staying low at 1% given I don‚Äôt know there‚Äôs a credible successor, but things could change quickly. From the Economist ‚ÄúMeanwhile, the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, who led the coup in 2014 in which the army (ostensibly in defence of the monarchy) seized power, grows less conciliatory by the day. In particular, a draconian law against ‚Äúinsulting‚Äù the monarchy has been dusted off and used against more than a score of activists. Mr Prayuth‚Äôs star, admittedly, is waning with the king, not least for letting the protests wax so dramatically. But if Mr Prayuth is dismissed as a scapegoat, it will surely be because King Vajiralongkorn wants his successor to take a harder line.‚Äù
Passage of time

temporarily boosting probability in anticipation of Constitutional court verdict tomorrow regarding his alleged staying in military quarters after retirement

Time to test Prayut? - Bangkok Post https://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/postbag/2026219/time-to-test-prayut- Fri, 27 Nov 2020 00:32:44 GMT > Despite HM the King's request that the lese majeste law not be implemented (which is in line with the wise advice of his great father), Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha has decided to ignore this request and has announced that "all laws" will be implemented to quell the current protest movement against his government.

He has been PM for 6 years and on Nov. 5 stated that he would be happy to have a better person replace him: https://www.thephuketnews.com/prayut-seeks-mr-right-to-take-over-top-job-77891.php As the 29th Prime Minister, he is already one of the longest serving PM's of Thailand - there is a slight possibility that he may go but Thailand is moving into a new era without the monarchy being the unifying force it once was and anything is possible
Thai premier warns of strict action against protesters https://www.aa.com.tr/en/asia-pacific/thai-premier-warns-of-strict-action-against-protesters/2048809

Lots of pressure within country. Difficult to say how it will be released. From the Economist ‚ÄúThailand‚Äôs political temperature keeps rising. This week pro-democracy protesters clashed with police and royalists in front of parliament. Police used tear-gas and water cannon (around 50 people were injured and a handful treated for gunshot wounds). Inside, MPs debated constitutional reforms‚Äîincluding curbs on royal powers and the army‚Äôs dominant role in politics, such as the students demand. The government has a majority and, being royalist and pro-army, it rejected progressive proposals to change the charter that it wrote in 2017. Parliament looks likely to establish a face-saving committee that will fiddle with the constitution but keep the old guard in power. Ultra-royalists continue calling for a coup to protect the monarchy. High-living King Vajiralongkorn remains constitutionally ‚Äúenthroned in a position of revered worship‚Äù. But under his reign, the monarchy‚Äôs hold on people‚Äôs imagination is much reduced. Today Prayuth Chan-ocha, the prime minister, warned protesters the state would use ‚Äúall the pertaining laws‚Äù against them. The country is entering risky territory‚Äú
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-protests/thousands-of-thai-protesters-call-for-removal-of-prime-minister-idUSKBN27U0A4

1. Last general election was in 2019. They are (supposed to be) held every three years. This places the next general election in 2022. 2. 40% of dictators will suffer an election loss and 12% who suffer an election loss will actually step down (https://oefresearch.org/think-peace/when-dictators-lose-elections). 3. With no election before 2022 and the statistics of 12% actually stepping down, this leads an outside view that is a low probability. 4. Protests don't often result in regime change (admit I could have dug more for a true base rate): https://www.pri.org/stories/2019-12-30/protests-rocked-world-2019 5. Inside view: protests in Thailand are widespread but the "personality"of the PM doesn't lead to a resignation.

I've never worked in a country where monarchist sentiment was so strong (and I'm a Brit!). As long as the king stands behind him, it seems extremely unlikely that these protests will weaken Prayut Chan-o-cha's position. So I'm making my prediction solely on the short-term possibility that a corruption scandal or similar will force him out.

Protesters are approaching is less likely to create a problem for PM than if they were directly going after him. MY prior is 14.7% (updated for passage of time), and my case specific probability is 5%. 75/25 weighting, to get to 12%.
Really a Military and Government controlled country?
Trimming a point with the passage of time.
He seems to be hanging on by a thread, losing military support, and king might throw him under the bus. Potential crackdown on protesters is less likely than coup at this moment.
I've touched on this previously.
Seems unlikely on an initial read. Seized power in military coup in 2014, won elections in 2019 (though it was close and may have been unfair), and no elections scheduled in near future.
Collecting the logic all in one place. My prior is based on three different criteria.

Staying fairly high on this. This guy is wildly unpopular. The king is increasingly looked at askance. He and his bedfellows in the military (the king has many bedfellows, mostly not fellows, but the military are the ones holding him up) will not want the PM's negatives to rub off on them any more than necessary. If things don't calm down, which they show little sign of doing, they may decide to throw him off the sleigh to the wolves in the hope of buying themselves some more time. This will probably work for a while longer.
Going up a little bit after discussion.
EDIT: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-25/thai-parliament-set-to-meet-in-shadow-of-fresh-wave-of-protests

As rather common with these questions on those in power, the prior should start with nothing will change. Read a few of the articles... I don't see anything that sways me away from that prior at the moment. Unfortunately doesn't sound like a great situation though.

He has the army and the king on his side, since 2014. It‚Äôs not like in a regime up since 1238, which the people is overall fond of (ok,ok a few glinches lately), they don‚Äôt know how to handle some protester. He has the king thrust and that‚Äôs enough. Protests are somewhat listened to from high up, but that‚Äôs all. Pretty much what Will happen in the US if Trump manages to stayüò¨. Turnover occurred in different circumstances. Decreasing soon.

Updating my base rate. If the average turnover is every two years, the base rate is 1- exp(ln(0.5)*t/2), where t is measured in years. That means a base rate of 16%. There is an awful lot of turmoil right now, but until I can see the parliamentary path for the toppling of this regime, sticking with the base rate.

Thailand has a history of political turmoil. The Prime Minister will not resign and his recent decision to move two military forces directly under his command indicate he'll go at great lengths to maintain his position.

This is interesting, because Prayut's power comes mainly from his association to the military, but the one who has backing among the people is the king. The king could replace him, e.g., by calling for new elections.

In retrospect one could have predicted this one much earlier. The Thais hate their king, who does not even live in the country (they loved the old king, his father). With tourism put to a halt anyways (due to Covid19), on which many people depend for their income, it is the perfect opportunity to try to get rid of the king (and with him Prayut Chan-o-cha - whose whole legitimacy is based on the king's backing), with lower personal economic cost.

The base rate for prime minister turnover is about 25%, based on there being 10 Thai prime ministers since 2000, so that‚Äôs one every two years and a 25% chance over 6 months. There was a general election in 2019 as well. There are conflicting other factors - such as the issues mentioned in the question, but also that he was installed by a military coup and so may not give up power easily. Will research it more, but for now sticking with base rate.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-54675173 ... Monarchy seldom gets involved, this is a clear indication of closing ranks and the barricades going up. The students want (not unfairly) to change the entire political system of Thailand ... The establishment are not going to go quietly. Possible fatal clashes incoming.
Baseline - Don't know...
While protests are ongoing, nothing leads me to believe Prayut Chan-o-cha will resign or be forced out in the immediate future.

Prayuth is not going to step down willingly.

I believe Prayut Chan-o-cha quells the protestors over the coming months.
